column1: CEFR Reading Practice Test – Full Version

column2: Millions and millions of these plants (1) in rivers and lakes. Sometimes the plants become so thick that people can walk on them. People cannot travel in boats on the water, and they cannot fish in it. The (2) stop the water from moving. Then the water carries diseases. Farmers cannot use the water on their land. Now scientists think that (3) hyacinths can be useful. The plants are really a free crop. No one has to take care of them. They just grow and grow. What can (4) use them for? Some fish like to eat them. Farmers can grow these fish in the lakes and rivers. Workers can collect and cut the plants with machines. Then they can make fertilizer to help crops grow better. They can also make animal feed. It may even be possible to make (5) gas for energy. Gas from plants is different from petroleum gas. Then poor tropical countries will not have to buy so much expensive (6).
column4: grow;plants;water;farmers;methane;petroleum
Jake and Maureen have different interests but both want to enjoy the same museum visit
Melanie wants her students to touch objects and take part in activities
Roger wants to learn about transport history and attend a talk
Kazuko wants to visit places where writers lived and see related pictures
Nick wants to learn about rivers and hills changing over time
Ingrid wants English history while her daughter wants flowers
Trevor wants to sketch small wildlife rather than large animals
Sarah and her husband want to spend time outdoors learning about history
Red House – a historic country home linked to the novelist Charlotte Brontë
Castle Museum – geology, fossils and the history of a river valley
Hillcrest Museum – hands-on archaeology with tools and computer programs
Shandy Hall – the former home of Laurence Sterne with drawings and gardens
Museum of Peace – exhibitions about peace history and non-violence
Fishing Centre – fishing history and the lives of fishermen’s families
Viking Centre – rebuilt Viking town with an introductory talk
Horsepower Museum – transport history with trams and daily lectures
Warwick Castle – medieval castle with exhibitions and gardens
Stratford Butterfly Farm – tropical butterflies and insects
Black Country Museum – open-air village showing traditional life
Drayton Manor – theme park with rides and a zoo

column2: Make Most of Your Free Time

column1: Guard your time;Make a difference;Why it’s so hard;Set a date;Get creative;Meet likeminded people;Change your life;Establish your goals;Do what you want;Plan ahead

Studies show that people today have more free time than before, yet many do not feel relaxed. Modern technology fills our free moments with information, preventing true rest.;;;Protect your free time by turning off your phone and ignoring household tasks so that work and leisure do not mix.;;;Many activities make us passive consumers. Creating something instead allows us to use different mental skills and feel refreshed.;;;Free time is not about impressing others or improving your résumé. It should be about enjoyment, not pressure.;;;Helping others through volunteering or community work can make free time more meaningful.;;;Once relaxed, people can reflect on how to improve their lives by joining clubs, classes or new activities.

column2: El Nino is a climate phenomenon that disrupts normal weather patterns and affects both human societies and wildlife. Scientists study it to understand its cycles and predict its impacts. Seabirds are important indicators of marine ecosystems because they depend on ocean resources for food. Changes in sea temperature and ice affect their survival. Marine mammals such as seals and sea lions have also shown signs of stress. Researchers believe long-term data is essential to understand these patterns fully.
Why do scientists study El Nino?
column4: To study marine animals only;To help societies plan for climate disruption;To prove a theory;Because it occurs in the Pacific

column2: Why are seabirds useful in climate studies?
column4: They are large;They respond quickly to food changes;They live near humans;They migrate far

column2: Ensuring our future food supply is becoming more important as climate change and disease threaten the crops we rely on. Many traditional seed varieties are disappearing, even though they may be vital for future survival.

Supermarkets prefer fruit and vegetables that are uniform in (1). Most people know about disappearing plants in (2), but few understand the loss of food diversity. In the USA, fewer than 100 varieties of (3) remain. Over (4) of food varieties worldwide have disappeared. This could lead to a global (5) as the world’s (6) continues to grow.
